meta.name: Tone-Emotion Mapping System
meta.description: Research-validated mappings of Mandarin tones to emotional archetypes
changes_from_v1: Tone 2: Changed from 'questioning' to 'surprised' to prevent L1 interference
Tone 3: Changed from 'brooding/dipping' to 'zombie/low/creaky' - focus on register, not contour
Added gesture, color, and voice quality specifications
meta.research_basis: L2 tone acquisition studies, NEVER model, embodied cognition research

1.name: First Tone (High-Level)

physical.gesture: Flat horizontal hand at forehead level, held steady
physical.voice_quality: Sustained, no declination, like holding a musical note

sentence_patterns: I sing '{sound}!' holding the note high and steady
The sound rings out '{sound}!' sustained like an opera note
I belt '{sound}!' and the note hangs in the air
1.l1_interference_warning: English speakers let pitch fall naturally. 'Singing' forces the sustain.

example.story: I trace a single line in the sky and SING 'YEEE!' - the note holds perfectly flat, ONE unbroken sound.

2.name: Second Tone (Rising)

physical.gesture: Sharp upward shrug, eyebrows raised, shoulders up

sentence_patterns: I gasp '{sound}?!' in shock as I witness it
I jolt upward, gasping '{sound}!' at the sight
2.l1_interference_warning: CRITICAL: Do NOT associate with syntactic questions. English speakers will apply T2 to all questions regardless of lexical tone. Frame as 'surprise reaction' not 'asking a question'. Drill T2 words in declarative sentences.

example.story: I see the cross marking treasure and GASP 'SHIH?!' - TEN gold coins burst from the ground!

3.name: Third Tone (Low)
3.contour: Low, creaky; full dip only in isolation

physical.gesture: Hand sinks low, palm down near hip, heavy
physical.voice_quality: Creaky voice (vocal fry), bottom of range, rumbling

sentence_patterns: I groan '{sound}...' from deep in my throat, voice creaking
A low rumble escapes: '{sound}...' like a zombie rising
I moan '{sound}' with creaky, gravelly voice
3.l1_interference_warning: CRITICAL: Do NOT teach as 'dipping'. In connected speech, T3 is almost never a full dip - it's just LOW. Focus on the creaky voice quality (vocal fry) at the bottom of the range. The 'dip-and-rise' only occurs in isolation or emphatic final position.
3.teaching_note: The creaky voice is not a defect - it's a secondary cue that helps distinguish T3 from T2. Native speakers naturally produce creaky phonation at low pitches.

example.story: FIVE rotting fingers burst from the grave, and the zombie GROANS 'Wuuuu...' in creaky, low agony.

4.name: Fourth Tone (Falling)

physical.voice_quality: Explosive, short duration, starts high and drops sharply

sentence_patterns: I COMMAND '{sound}!' with a sharp bark
I SHOUT '{sound}!' and my hand chops down
The word EXPLODES out: '{sound}!' decisive and final
4.l1_interference_warning: This tone aligns well with English emphatic stress. Ensure the starting pitch is HIGH enough - learners often start too low. 'Commanding' triggers the necessary high onset.

example.story: I SLAM four items into the box and COMMAND 'SEE!' - my hand chops down with each count.

5.name: Fifth Tone (Neutral)

physical.voice_quality: Reduced, attached to previous syllable, throwaway

sentence_patterns: ...and I toss out '{sound}' as an afterthought

example.story: The arrow hits the target and I mumble 'duh' - just a throwaway connector.

T2-T3.description: The most difficult transition. Rising energy must immediately sink to creaky low.
T2-T3.example: méiguǐ (rose): I GASP 'MAY-' in surprise, then GROAN '-gway' from the grave

T3-T3_sandhi.description: Two zombies can't coexist. First one 'wakes up' (becomes T2).
T3-T3_sandhi.mnemonic: Two zombies fighting - one has to come alive!
T3-T3_sandhi.example: nǐ hǎo: I gasp 'NEE' (waking up) then groan 'how' (still dead)

T4-T4.example: dàjiào: I SHOUT 'DAH!' and SHOUT 'jow!' - two explosive barks

third_tone_sandhi.mnemonic: Two zombies can't stand together. One must wake up (become surprised) to make room.

yi_sandhi.teaching: Learn as chunks: yígè, yìdiǎn, etc.

bu_sandhi.teaching: Learn as chunks: búshì, búyào, etc.

integration_with_stories.principle: Every story must encode the tone through verb choice

examples.T1_example: Tree → I SING 'MOOO!' as the wood rings with one clear note
examples.T2_example: Field → I GASP 'TYEN?!' seeing the rice flooded
examples.T3_example: Mouth → The jaw unhinges and GROANS 'kohhh...' from its depths
examples.T4_example: Sun → Light COMMANDS 'REE!' blasting me awake
